Literature Review: Zoos and aquariums have undergone a significant transformation over the years, shifting from their initial role as venues for public entertainment to becoming pivotal institutions in biodiversity conservation, environmental education, and scientific research. This evolution reflects a broader societal recognition of the urgent need to address the biodiversity crisis and the role that these institutions can play in mitigating it. The literature underscores the multifaceted roles of modern zoos and aquariums, highlighting their contributions to conservation efforts, educational outreach, and the advancement of scientific knowledge, while also acknowledging the criticisms and challenges they face. Conservation is one of the primary roles of contemporary zoos and aquariums, with many institutions actively participating in captive breeding programs aimed at preserving endangered species. These programs often serve as a last resort for species on the brink of extinction, providing a safety net that can help to stabilize or even increase their populations. For example, the successful captive breeding and subsequent reintroduction of the California condor (Gymnogyps californianus) into the wild is frequently cited as a testament to the potential of these programs to contribute to species recovery (Ralls & Ballou, 2004). Moreover, zoos and aquariums play a crucial role in educating the public about biodiversity and the importance of conservation. Through interactive exhibits, educational programs, and outreach initiatives, these institutions have the unique ability to engage visitors of all ages, fostering a deeper understanding and appreciation of the natural world. Research has shown that visits to zoos and aquariums can significantly increase visitors' knowledge of biodiversity and their willingness to engage in conservation actions (Falk et al., 2007). In addition to their conservation and educational roles, zoos and aquariums are also important centers for scientific research. Studies conducted in these settings can provide valuable insights into animal behavior, physiology, and genetics, contributing to our broader understanding of biodiversity and informing conservation strategies. For instance, research on the reproductive biology of captive animals has led to advancements in assisted reproductive technologies, which have been applied to both captive and wild populations (Holt et al., 2003). Despite these contributions, zoos and aquariums face criticism regarding the welfare of animals in their care and the effectiveness of their conservation efforts. Critics argue that the conditions in which animals are kept can lead to stress and behavioral abnormalities, raising ethical concerns about the captivity of wild animals (Mason, 2010). Furthermore, the success of conservation programs is sometimes questioned, with some studies suggesting that the impact of captive breeding and reintroduction programs on the recovery of wild populations may be limited (Snyder et al., 1996). In response to these challenges, many zoos and aquariums are adopting more holistic approaches to animal care and conservation, emphasizing the importance of animal welfare and the need for integrated conservation strategies that include habitat protection and restoration (Hosey et al., 2009). Additionally, there is a growing recognition of the need for these institutions to engage more directly with local communities and to contribute to the conservation of species in their natural habitats (Barongi et al., 2015). Looking to the future, the role of zoos and aquariums in a changing world will likely continue to evolve. As societal expectations and environmental challenges grow, these institutions will need to adapt and innovate to remain relevant and effective in their conservation, educational, and research missions. This may involve the development of new technologies and methodologies for animal care and conservation, as well as the strengthening of partnerships with other conservation organizations and stakeholders (Conde et al., 2011). In conclusion, zoos and aquariums have the potential to make significant contributions to biodiversity conservation, environmental education, and scientific research. However, realizing this potential will require addressing the criticisms and challenges they face, and continuously adapting to the changing needs of both the natural world and society.
